articles.headline: Ruling Likely to Spur Convictions in Capital Cases
articles.snippet: Experts said a Supreme Court decision will make juries in death penalty cases whiter and more conviction-prone.
articles.abstract: Experts said a Supreme Court decision will make juries in death penalty cases whiter and more conviction-prone.
articles.lead_paragraph: A decision by the Supreme Court on Monday that made it easier for prosecutors to exclude people who express reservations about the death penalty from capital juries will make the panels whiter and more conviction-prone, experts in law and psychology said this week.

articles.headline: Celebrity Justice Cuts Both Ways for Paris Hilton
articles.snippet: In the socialite’s case, the national obsession with celebrity collided with the issue of the equal application of justice.
articles.abstract: In the socialite’s case, the national obsession with celebrity collided with the issue of the equal application of justice.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, June 8 — The national obsession with celebrity collided head-on with the more serious issue of the equal application of justice on Friday, as a judge sent the socialite Paris Hilton back to jail some 36 hours after she was released for an unspecified medical problem.

articles.headline: Caution: Lower Truck Sales Ahead
articles.snippet: As with sport utilities, the popularity of pickups is in decline.
articles.abstract: As with sport utilities, the popularity of pickups is in decline.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, June 8 — For most of their history, pickups have been to auto companies what they were to their customers: reliable workhorses, with Detroit counting on them for big sales and profits even as flashier cars came and went.

articles.headline: Trade Deficit Narrowed a Bit in April
articles.snippet: Growth has slowed in the United States, but economies in Asia and Europe are surging and snatching up more and more American exports.
articles.abstract: Growth has slowed in the United States, but economies in Asia and Europe are surging and snatching up more and more American exports.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States’ trade imbalance with the rest of the world narrowed slightly in April, providing a tentative sign that less-lopsided trade could help lift the economy this year.

articles.headline: Ample Jobs, but Youths Are Choosy
articles.snippet: For youths who want to work this summer, the job market is strong. The bigger question seems to be: Who is going to take them?
articles.abstract: For youths who want to work this summer, the job market is strong. The bigger question seems to be: Who is going to take them?
articles.lead_paragraph: For youths who want to work this summer, the job market is strong, offering a wide range of employment opportunities. The bigger question seems to be, Who is going to take them?

articles.headline: Quantifying the Role of School Ties in Investing
articles.snippet: Mutual fund managers invest more money in companies that are run by people they knew in school, a study says.
articles.abstract: Mutual fund managers invest more money in companies that are run by people they knew in school, a study says.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new study circulating through hedge funds and university campuses points to the powerful role that old-school ties play in the world of investing.

articles.headline: Running G.E., Comfortable in His Skin
articles.snippet: Jeff Immelt is the prototype of the modern chief executive.
articles.abstract: Jeff Immelt is the prototype of the modern chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: “When you put your foot on the gas in this company,” Jeffrey R. Immelt said a few weeks ago, with just the slightest trace of a satisfied smile, “the car goes forward.”

articles.headline: For One Visit, Bush Will Feel Pro-U.S. Glow
articles.snippet: In Albania, which has not wavered in its support for American policies, President Bush can do no wrong.
articles.abstract: In Albania, which has not wavered in its support for American policies, President Bush can do no wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIRANA, Albania, June 8 — The highlight of President Bush’s European tour may well be his visit on Sunday to this tiny country, one of the few places left where he can bask in unabashed pro-American sentiment without a protester in sight.

articles.headline: Hispanic Voters Gain New Clout With Democrats
articles.snippet: The immigration battle and the new presidential primary schedule have amplified the influence of Hispanic voters.
articles.abstract: The immigration battle and the new presidential primary schedule have amplified the influence of Hispanic voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 9 — Helped by the fight over immigration, Democratic presidential candidates are courting Hispanic voters like never before, prompted by a string of early primaries in states with sizable Hispanic voting blocs.

articles.headline: Corporate Korea Corks the Bottle as Women Rise
articles.snippet: As more women join the ranks, Korea’s male-centered corporate culture is changing, starting with alcohol.
articles.abstract: As more women join the ranks, Korea’s male-centered corporate culture is changing, starting with alcohol.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — In a time-honored practice in South Korea’s corporate culture, the 38-year-old manager at an online game company took his 10-person team on twice-weekly after-work drinking bouts. He exhorted his subordinates to drink, including a 29-year-old graphic designer who protested that her limit was two glasses of beer.

articles.headline: Microsoft Finds Legal Defender in Justice Dept.
articles.snippet: A company the government once tried to break up has been repeatedly defended by the Bush administration against charges of anticompetitive conduct.
articles.abstract: A company the government once tried to break up has been repeatedly defended by the Bush administration against charges of anticompetitive conduct.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 9 — Nearly a decade after the government began its landmark effort to break up Microsoft, the Bush administration has sharply changed course by repeatedly defending the company both in the United States and abroad against accusations of anticompetitive conduct, including the recent rejection of a complaint by Google.

articles.headline: Goldman Runs Risks, Reaps Rewards
articles.snippet: Even though Goldman Sachs is the most imitated and envied investment bank around, its chief executive is still intent on proving his firm to the world.
articles.abstract: Even though Goldman Sachs is the most imitated and envied investment bank around, its chief executive is still intent on proving his firm to the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: LLOYD C. BLANKFEIN, chief executive of one of the most wildly profitable financial firms in the world, rifles through his trash searching for a thank-you note. He has a point to make. Yes, his firm, Goldman Sachs, wasn’t chosen to underwrite the Blackstone Group’s planned initial public offering, but there are plenty of other Goldman clients grateful for the firm’s services and Mr. Blankfein is going to find the note that proves it.

articles.headline: Taking On Alzheimer’s
articles.snippet: Virtually every large drug maker is working to develop Alzheimer’s drugs, seeking to improve treatment and possibly snare a big  financial payoff.
articles.abstract: Virtually every large drug maker is working to develop Alzheimer’s drugs, seeking to improve treatment and possibly snare a big  financial payoff.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN the book “Mrs. Frisby and the Rats of NIMH,” a group of lab rats acquire human intelligence through a genetic experiment. Every child recognizes the charming tale as pure fantasy, yet something similar is occurring at a major pharmaceuticals company, Wyeth, where rodents tested in its labs have, indeed, taken on some features of the human brain.

articles.headline: Chinese Leave Guantánamo for Albanian Limbo
articles.snippet: Five former prisoners have been given asylum by Albania’s government, but have received little else.
articles.abstract: Five former prisoners have been given asylum by Albania’s government, but have received little else.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIRANA, Albania — Ahktar Qassim Basit says he is not angry about the four years he spent as an American prisoner at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, before his captors mumbled a brief apology and flew him to this drab Balkan capital to begin a new life as a refugee.

articles.headline: Beware of Exploding Mortgages
articles.snippet: A tsunami of interest rate increases on adjustable-rate mortgages is coming, meaning that the worst of the subprime lending fiasco is far from over.
articles.abstract: A tsunami of interest rate increases on adjustable-rate mortgages is coming, meaning that the worst of the subprime lending fiasco is far from over.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANYONE who believes that the worst is over in the subprime mortgage fiasco need merely wait awhile. A tsunami of interest rate increases on these loans is headed your way.

articles.headline: In Return Home to Mexico Grave, an Industry Rises
articles.snippet: For many Mexicans the sojourn to the United States, legal or not, is meant to be temporary.
articles.abstract: For many Mexicans the sojourn to the United States, legal or not, is meant to be temporary.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONWAY, Ark. — Héctor Acevedo was 22, in this country illegally and far from his mother when he died last month in a car accident outside of town just across the Arkansas River.

articles.headline: Romney’s Run Has Mormons Wary of Scrutiny
articles.snippet: For many Mormons, Mitt Romney’s bid for president is both a proud sign of progress and a cause of trepidation.
articles.abstract: For many Mormons, Mitt Romney’s bid for president is both a proud sign of progress and a cause of trepidation.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOGAN, Utah — In this wide valley where the twin spires of the Mormon temple dominate the landscape and some neighborhoods have a Mormon chapel every few blocks, Mitt Romney’s bid for president is both a proud sign of progress and a cause of trepidation.

articles.headline: States Finding Fiscal Surprise: A Cash Surplus
articles.snippet: Lawmakers in more than 40 states have found themselves with more money than they had expected.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers in more than 40 states have found themselves with more money than they had expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: State lawmakers across the country, their coffers unexpectedly full of cash, have been handing out tax cuts, spending money on fixing roads, schools and public buildings, and socking something away for less fruitful years.

articles.headline: A TheirSpace for Drug Sales Reps
articles.snippet: Drug and medical-device sales representatives hash out their lives and work in tens of thousands of discussion threads at cafepharma.com
articles.abstract: Drug and medical-device sales representatives hash out their lives and work in tens of thousands of discussion threads at cafepharma.com
articles.lead_paragraph: THE drug sales representative was expecting a $12,000 performance bonus. Unfortunately, the rep’s chance to jump to a better job at another drug company required that the move be made a month before the bonus would be issued. Was it possible to start the new job without the old employer knowing and still collect the bonus?

articles.headline: Who Pays for Efficiency?
articles.snippet: The quest to save dollars in the nation’s $2.1 trillion annual health care bill is becoming a lucrative market of its own.
articles.abstract: The quest to save dollars in the nation’s $2.1 trillion annual health care bill is becoming a lucrative market of its own.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAVING money can be expensive.

articles.headline: U.S. Arming Sunnis in Iraq to Battle Old Qaeda Allies
articles.snippet: Commanders are arming groups that have promised to fight militants who have been their allies in the past.
articles.abstract: Commanders are arming groups that have promised to fight militants who have been their allies in the past.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, June 10 — With the four-month-old increase in American troops showing only modest success in curbing insurgent attacks, American commanders are turning to another strategy that they acknowledge is fraught with risk: arming Sunni Arab groups that have promised to fight militants linked with Al Qaeda who have been their allies in the past.
articles.byline: By John F. Burns and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: Top Editor Is Leaving Book Post
articles.snippet: Daniel Menaker, the executive editor in chief of the Random House Publishing Group, is leaving the company at the end of June.
articles.abstract: Daniel Menaker, the executive editor in chief of the Random House Publishing Group, is leaving the company at the end of June.
articles.lead_paragraph: Daniel Menaker, the executive editor in chief of the Random House Publishing Group who was hired four years ago for his strong literary credentials, is leaving the company at the end of June.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Motoko Rich

articles.headline: Marketers Are Joining the Varsity
articles.snippet: Marketing and media companies are now capitalizing on consumer interest in high school sports and becoming big boosters of them.
articles.abstract: Marketing and media companies are now capitalizing on consumer interest in high school sports and becoming big boosters of them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Athletes, if they are talented, train hard and get a break or two, can climb the sports ladder from high school to college to the pros. Madison Avenue, sensing a lucrative opportunity, is heading the other way.

articles.headline: A Dog or a Cat? New Tests to Fool Automated Spammers
articles.snippet: Several Internet companies, including Microsoft and eBay, are working on new ways to keep spammers from infiltrating their sites.
articles.abstract: Several Internet companies, including Microsoft and eBay, are working on new ways to keep spammers from infiltrating their sites.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the Internet, nobody knows you’re a human — until you fill out a captcha.

articles.headline: Call the Doctor
articles.snippet: The controversy over the drug Avandia demonstrates how the Web seems better-suited to Paris Hilton than patient safety.
articles.abstract: The controversy over the drug Avandia demonstrates how the Web seems better-suited to Paris Hilton than patient safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the news broke last month that significant questions had been raised about an increase in the risk of a heart attack for users of Avandia, I followed the reports with a bit more avidity than most.

articles.headline: At Creative Artists, a Bit of Blushing After a Corporate Kiss-Off
articles.snippet: In the new Hollywood, agencies are finding it can be tougher to meet the needs of a corporate customer than to baby-sit for a temperamental star.
articles.abstract: In the new Hollywood, agencies are finding it can be tougher to meet the needs of a corporate customer than to baby-sit for a temperamental star.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, June 10 — For the powers at the Creative Artists Agency, Hollywood’s pre-eminent talent representative, the coming blockbuster “Transformers” has already brought a lesson in the cold-hearted ways of corporate entertainment.

articles.headline: What’s the Flavor of the Month? Medical Devices.
articles.snippet: Venture capitalists are pouring money into medical-device companies at the expense of past favorites like computer-related start-ups or drug-development companies.
articles.abstract: Venture capitalists are pouring money into medical-device companies at the expense of past favorites like computer-related start-ups or drug-development companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUKE EVNIN contends there is money to be made giving people with fading vision a poke in the eye.
